title: 104_hr2429
content: The "Farms for the Future Act Amendments of 1995" aims to provide financially competitive options for agricultural producers to maintain prime, unique, and strategic farmland in agricultural production. Congress recognizes the need for federal assistance to protect these lands due to the lack of incentives from states and local governments. The Farms for the Future Act Amendments of 1995 aim to provide federal cost-sharing for the acquisition of farmland protection easements under a new section added to the existing Act. The Farms for the Future Act Amendments of 1995 introduce definitions related to farmland protection easements, including qualifying farmland and eligible states. Eligible states must have a program approved by the Secretary to acquire farmland protection easements. The Farms for the Future Act Amendments of 1995 establish a program for eligible states to acquire farmland protection easements. The Secretary may provide matching grants to assist in acquiring these easements, with a 50-50 matching requirement. Matching grants under subsection (c) are provided on a 50-50 matching basis, but the Secretary has the discretion to offer grants for up to 90 percent of the cost of acquiring farmland protection easements for eligible States actively working to protect farmland. An eligible State cannot receive more than 10 percent of the total grants available for a fiscal year. The Secretary must ensure that funds are used to protect qualifying farmland, prioritizing lands crucial to the State's agriculture industry. The Secretary ensures funds are used to protect qualifying farmland, prioritizing lands important to the State's agriculture industry. Purchase price of farmland protection easements acquired should not exceed fair market value. Authorization of appropriations is provided for each fiscal year.
